<SOURCE>http://siouxcityjournal.com/news/local/a1/jeb-bush-draws-in-first-sioux-city-campaign-stop/article_3f12a561-655f-5a2f-af2c-01d29abfcebe.html</SOURCE>
<DATE_TIME>2015-07-13T00:00:00</DATE_TIME>
<HEADLINE>
Jeb Bush would end fuel rule that aids Iowa ethanol industry
</HEADLINE>
<TEXT>
SIOUX CITY | Republican presidential candidate Jeb Bush on Monday again
asserted a position that could give him trouble with some Iowa voters, as he
supports an end to a federal rule that helps the ethanol industry.
Asked about his position on the Renewable Fuel Standard during his first Sioux
City campaign stop since becoming a candidate in June, Bush said, "We need to
phase that out over the long haul."
The RFS federal rule holds that gasoline be composed of up to 10 percent
renewable fuels. Iowa farmers are the top producers nationally of corn, which
is placed into an ethanol fuel blend.
Bush said he understands there are more than 70,000 ethanol-related jobs in
Iowa. He had also spoken against the RFS in March in Iowa, before becoming a
candidate.
Bush drew 240 people in his stop, where he vowed to deliver "competency and
conservative principles" to lead the U.S. to a new era of growth.
"I want to win ... I will run with heart, I will run with conviction," Bush
said.
He vowed to not compete solely in Republican-leaning venues in seeking the
nomination.
"You will see me competing in the Latino communities, campaigning in English
and in Spanish, because I can," Bush said.
Bush is a former two-term Florida governor, and a son and brother of former
presidents George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush. He noted that as governor he
cut the state government workforce by 11 percent, or 13,000 workers, helped
create 1.3 million jobs elsewhere and income growth went up by 4.4 percent
annually.
Bush's stop came on the same day that Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker launched his
campaign, in Waukesha County, Wisconsin. Walker has led in recent Iowa polls,
while Bush had big news last week that he and the affiliated Right To Rise
political action group drew $114 million in campaign cash in the last quarter.
That dwarfs the funding by any other candidates who have announced results in
Federal Election Commission reports due July 15.
The Bush event marks a big week in Sioux City, as Bush and two of his principal
rivals for the Republican nomination -- Walker and U.S. Sen. Marco Rubio,
R-Fla. -- make their first campaign appearances in the city after joining the
race.
Bush spoke for 45 minutes, with three-fourths of that time devoted to nine
questions from the audience. Rod Webber, of Boston, who described himself as a
liberal, presented Bush with a large bouquet of black-eyed Susans. The two had
also met in a New Hampshire event, Bush noted.
Bush eventually agreed with Webber's request to pray jointly for the nation.
Bush left the flowers behind as he departed the venue.
Two people said Bush is among their top four candidates. Mary Ann Irwin, of
Denison, Iowa, also likes Walker, Rubio and Arkansas Gov. Bobby Jindal.
"I am beginning to lean more toward people who have been governors," Irwin said.
Marlo Griebel, former coach of the 1981 state champion Paullina boys basketball
team, now lives in Sioux City. Griebel said Bush has a good grasp of the
economy.
"I respect the Bush family so much that I wanted to see Jeb," Griebel said. "He
was a good governor, and he'd make a good president."
Bush slammed the policies of Democratic President Barack Obama. He also quickly
criticized Hillary Clinton, the Democratic candidate polling leader, three
times within the first three minutes. He said the goal for economic growth
nationally should be 4 percent annually, while asserting Clinton's plan
unveiled Monday wouldn't aim that high.
In a news conference before the Bush event, state Rep. Chris Hall, D-Sioux
City, criticized Bush's statement of last week that in order to grow the
economy, Americans need to work longer hours.
Bush said he would pursue reform in the Social Security and Medicare
entitlement programs, including raising the retirement age at which Americans
can access Social Security benefits.
A member of the First Budget advocacy group asked Bush for his plans to balance
the federal deficit. Bush said he supports a hiring freeze on federal workers
and that not replacing retirees would reduce costs.
"You are not going to get it to balance immediately, but with high (economic)
growth and a focused approach to limiting spending, including entitlements over
the long haul, you can get it in balance. Without (the economy) growing, it
won't happen. And if we don't fix the entitlement system, it won't happen,"
Bush said.
Bush spoke in the same Morningside College auditorium that Republican
candidates Ted Cruz, a U.S. senator from Texas, and businesswoman Carly
Fiorinia used. As with Cruz, there was an overflow crowd to see Bush, and some
sat outside the 200-seat venue.
</TEXT>
